title: Did the soldiers who died in a battle in World War One get buried where they fell and if so does that mean that the majority of the graves in northern France are just a gravestone memorial? - Quora

response.answer_text: Many soldiers were buried in temporary graveyards not far behind the lines. This was because there was no way to preserve the bodies and there were so many of them. It was a matter of hygiene to remove the dead from the battlefield, and no-one would risk exposing themselves to dig a grave in the battle area. When official cemeteries were later created, the bodies were exhumed and moved to the permanent cemeteries. Since WWI bodies have been found all over the battlefields. Today, such a body will be carefully exhumed in an attempt to preserve any identification, and efforts are made to identify them. They will usually be formally buried, with military honors, in one of the permanent cemeteries. In Australia, the families of the deceased were asked if they would like a line or two on the headstone, and these can be seen for some of the Australian troops. Because of the shelling, it was very easy for a soldier to simply disappear. Getting deeply buried while sheltering was not unusual, and a wounded man could drown in the mud in a shell crater, then get buried by the next explosion. While bodies were recovered, identification was difficult and often impossible. One of my own cousins was last seen heading towards the front line at Bullecourt, and was never seen again. No body was found that could be identified as his, so he just has his name on a memorial in France. The gravestones in northern France mark a real body (or parts thereof), and they did try to identify each body, but it was not always possible to determine even which side they had been on. In some cemeteries, the headstone simply reads “A Soldier of the Great War.” The graves and the cemeteries are beautifully maintained and it is possible to find any grave for someone that was identified. If you happen to visit Ypres, there is a memorial to the Battles of the Somme from 1915 to 1917, which lists the names of the British and South African troops who were killed but never found (other nationalities have memorials elsewhere). So these soldiers do not have a known grave anywhere. There are 75,000 names on that one memorial. The Commonwealth War Graves Commission does an outstanding job of caring for these cemeteries and memorials, and honoring the memory of these fallen soldiers.

For the British Army there were volunteer troops in France and Belgium clearing battlefields and recovering bodies, and many of these men suffered immense mental and alcohol problems in later life (they were allowed a virtually unlimited Rum ration to cope with the gruesome task) Many of the cemeteries actually mark the spot where field hospitals and casualty clearing stations were sited, so as to minimise the movement of bodies, other were collected from various parts of the battlefield to the nearest one Other cemeteries were established where significant fighting took place and large concentrations of bodies were found Each one found was collected, identification was attempted, and the body buried Each Commonwealth Grave represents one body (or body part) of a soldier, whilst the German authorities use the standard of 1 headstone for 2 bodies Many graves carry no identification at all just the statement “known only to god” because “dog tags” were not an issued item (though many purchased them privately) so indemnification relied on surviving documents and uniform details, though in recent years this has been extended to DNA testing

Walk amongst the graves, some give their names etc because others say known unto God meaning nobody knows except who they are except God. Now go to the Menin Gate at Ypres Belgium at 8 pm and hear the last post in sound in memory of one of 75,000 known only to God. There is a full range of every nation in the British Empire here who gave themselves to keep Europe free.

Given the preponderance of casualties to artillery in WWI, a large number of those killed were left little more than a puddle of faceless goo, so your contention would seem on the whole to be correct.
